title: Don Ramon Briefing on Council Meeting

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning sun has climbed higher over Barcelona by the time you emerge from the bishop's study. The bells of Santa Eulàlia toll the end of Terce somewhere behind you, their bronze voices echoing through the narrow streets of the Barri Gòtic.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, Don Ramon de Perellós awaits in the regent's council chamber. He sent word asking whether you wished him to attend you here, or if you preferred to meet in the Palau Reial.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back to the palace would take perhaps a quarter hour through the winding streets. The morning air is crisp but not cold—mild for January, even by Mediterranean standards. Lucia remained at the palace with Catalina after your departure for the bishop's meeting. The Consell de Cent, Barcelona's powerful city council and merchant guilds, expects you at midday. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience for the afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will visit the regent in his palace. We go there now.

encounters.recap: After his meeting with Bishop Climent, Juan decides to meet with Don Ramon de Perellós at the Palau Reial to discuss court administration and the itinerary for his remaining time in Barcelona, with other important meetings scheduled for the day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Palau Reial rises at the heart of the old city—less imposing than Toledo's Alcázar, but older, its stones worn smooth by centuries of Catalan counts and Aragonese kings. The guards at the gate snap to attention as you approach, and a steward appears almost immediately to escort you through the courtyard.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon de Perellós receives you in the regent's council chamber—a long room dominated by a heavy oak table and tapestries depicting the conquest of Majorca. He rises from behind a desk cluttered with documents, bowing precisely.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Majesty. I trust the morning has been productive. I have prepared a proposed itinerary for Your Majesty's remaining time in Barcelona. The Consell de Cent at midday, as arranged. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience—I have suggested the fourth hour after noon, if that suits. Don Guillem de Vic wishes to present certain communications he has drafted on Your Majesty's behalf. I understand Your Majesty visited Bishop Climent Sapera this morning. A lengthy meeting, by all accounts.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for the effort and care you took for facilitating these meetings. I trust there are issues or matters you yourself want to discuss with us as well? We are here and you have our ear.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon inclines his head at Juan's offer, his expression revealing nothing. He does not immediately continue. Instead, he moves to the window, adjusting the angle of a shutter as if the light offended him. When he turns back, his hands are clasped behind his back—the posture of a man preparing to deliver a report.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. The matter of the itinerary is not... merely logistical. Barcelona is not Toledo, Your Majesty. The Consell de Cent guards its prerogatives jealously. The Count of Pallars speaks for nobles who remember when Aragón's king lived in Aragón. The merchants want to know whether Castilian trade agreements will respect Catalan privileges. In four years as head of the regency council, I have learned that scheduling is governance. Who sees the king, and when, and in what order—these things matter. They send signals. They create expectations. They establish... hierarchies. Your Majesty arrived yesterday evening. Since then, you have spoken privately with Don Guillem de Vic, with the Count of Pallars, and this morning—at considerable length—with Bishop Climent Sapera. The regency council was not consulted regarding any of these conversations. Queen María has requested that I coordinate all further meetings through Her Majesty's secretary. She wishes to be informed in advance of Your Majesty's appointments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I appologize immediately for not consulting with you sooner. An oversight I cannot take back. You have my word that not seeing you sooner was somehow a deliberate act to undermine your authority or to diminish it. I simply took audiences with anyone willing to speak with me. But now that we are here, what matters should we discuss? And what are the concerns of the regency council?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon accepts the apology with a slight bow—correct, minimal. He does not say accepted. He does not say of course or think nothing of it. He simply... notes it.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's word is noted. Your Majesty asks what the council's concerns are. That is a... complex question. The council's concerns depend greatly on circumstances. On what is being proposed. On what commitments may already have been made. I have served as head of this council for four years. In that time, I have learned that I cannot advise a king on what he should do until I understand what he has done. Don Guillem de Vic left the reception last night speaking of 'great things to come' and 'bringing the kingdoms together.' The Count of Pallars sent a messenger to his estates at first light—I do not know why. Bishop Climent Sapera has reportedly cancelled his morning appointments to draft letters to the Archbishop of Tarragona. What should the regency council's concerns be, Your Majesty? What has been discussed? What has been offered? What expectations now exist that did not exist two days ago?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I tell the regent exactly what has happened and do not hold back. I tell him about my vision for a better world and how bringing the kingdoms closer together might help this. That I have been able to share this vision with others who are now also trying to achieve this. That the kingdoms uniting should not be Aragon joining Castille, but both kingdoms joining to become something else with neither holding dominance. I also tell him that I talked about the crown succession with Maria. And that I should have asked her about the current situation regarding succession and my own role in this. Something I am still curious about. What will actually happen should king Alfonso die?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon listens without interruption. His face remains carefully composed throughout—the practiced stillness of a man who has spent decades hearing kings and nobles speak of grand designs. When Juan finishes, Don Ramon is silent for a long moment. He moves to the window again, looking out at the courtyard below where servants cross on their errands.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has been... remarkably candid. You ask about the succession. That, at least, is a matter of law rather than vision. King Alfonso has no legitimate children. Queen María has borne none, and the physicians hold little hope after so many years. Should Alfonso die, the Crown of Aragón passes to his nearest male relative. The Infantes Juan and Enrique are dead. Their legitimate male issue—Carlos of Viana—is also dead. This leaves... King Ferdinand of Aragón, Alfonso's father, had one other son who survived infancy. That son married into the House of Trastámara. His daughter María is our regent. His son... His son is Your Majesty. By strict succession law, should Alfonso die without heir, the Crown of Aragón would pass to the descendants of Ferdinand's second son—that is, to Juan II of Castile. Your Majesty is, in fact, Alfonso's heir presumptive. The regency council is aware of this. The factions are aware of this. When Your Majesty speaks of 'bringing kingdoms together,' every man in Barcelona hears it through this lens. I would suggest that further discussions regarding succession—or visions of unity—include Her Majesty the Regent and the full council. These are not matters for private conversations with faction leaders and bishops. Is there anything else Your Majesty requires for the midday reception with the Consell de Cent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You indicate that further discussions about unity should include the full council. Since everybody seems to be thinking about this already, can such a meeting be arranged?

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Don Ramon de Perellós, who confronts him about bypassing the regency council in his private meetings with various factions. Juan apologizes and reveals his vision for uniting the kingdoms as equals, not through Castilian dominance. Don Ramon responds cautiously, revealing that Juan is actually Alfonso's heir presumptive to the Crown of Aragón, which explains why his unity discussions alarm everyone. The regent insists future succession talks must include the full council.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Saló de Cent—the Hall of the Hundred—occupies the heart of the Casa de la Ciutat, a stern stone building that speaks of civic pride and commercial power. Inside, the hall is smaller than Toledo's throne room but no less impressive in its way. Pointed arches rise to a wooden ceiling painted in red and gold. The walls bear the arms of Barcelona—the red and gold bars of Aragón quartered with the cross of Sant Jordi. Wooden benches line the chamber in rising tiers, and upon them sit the jurats: one hundred men in dark robes and furred caps, the elected governors of one of the Mediterranean's greatest trading cities.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesties of Castile. Barcelona welcomes you. I am Pere Joan de Sant Climent, conseller en cap. We are honored by your presence in our city. We understand Your Majesty has recently achieved a great victory against the Moor. The Consell wishes to offer its congratulations. Granada's fall is a triumph for all Christendom. We also understand that Granada's ports now fly Castilian banners. Málaga. Almería. Ports that once competed with Barcelona for the African trade. Perhaps Your Majesty would honor us by sharing how Castile intends to... organize these new commercial opportunities?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for granting us audience and to introduce us to this chamber and this intricate system of governance. I am here with my queen to meet with my sister and to learn about Catalan customs. You ask specifically about how to exploit the trade in Grenada. I must confess that I have not yet made any major decisions. Maybe I should summon all the traders in the region in one council and come up with a system or structure for trade. But I can already tell you what my aim is going to be; I want trade to increase and cooperation as well. There are many fields where Aragonese and Castillian interests align. Already I am moving against Muslim piracy that has plagued our coasts for so long. Areas where Castille can indeed draw upon the expertise of friends like Aragon, should they choose to give it.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentions summoning traders to create a system. A worthy thought. Might we ask—which traders? Castilian traders from Seville, who already control the Atlantic routes? Or will Catalan houses receive equal voice in this... council? Your Majesty speaks of cooperation. Of aligned interests. We hear these words and we are grateful for them. But Your Majesty will forgive us—we are merchants. We think in contracts, not sentiments. When Málaga's harbor opens to Christian trade, will a Catalan ship pay the same duties as a Castilian ship? Will Barcelona's cloth merchants have the same rights in Granada's markets as Burgos wool factors? These are not challenges, Your Majesty. Merely... the questions that keep merchants awake at night.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe I should take a step back and let you explain what you are really concerned about. And what a king such as I could do to adress them. I do not set or control prices of trade goods. If Grenada weavers choose to now enter the Christian market, they are free to do so. My question to you would be: Is this not free commerce? Please tell me what a king of a kingdom not even your own gathers so much interest from this council.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks a fair question. You are correct. You are King of Castile. Aragonese trade policy is a matter for King Alfonso and the regency council. We overstep. And yet. Your Majesty will forgive us if we speak plainly. We are Catalans. Plainness is our vice. King Alfonso pursues his destiny in Naples. Queen María holds Aragón in trust. And the man who stands before us today is... a man of great consequence. A man who has achieved what no Christian king has achieved in two centuries. A man whose shadow falls long across all of Iberia.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks what a Castilian king could do to address our concerns. The answer is simple: nothing. Today. But we are merchants. We plan for tomorrow. We sign contracts that bind our grandchildren. We think in generations. Every man in this chamber knows the succession laws of Aragón. Every man knows that King Alfonso has no heir. Every man knows who stands next in line. We do not ask Your Majesty to make promises you cannot keep. We ask only... to understand what kind of king you are. Whether you see Barcelona as a partner or as a... subject.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask me what kind of king I am. That I can do. Though I risk a bit of pride about my accomplishments, but I have taken my queen with me, who is sure to let me know when I do. When developing trade policy, I ask myself one question. What will increase trade the most? What develops ports? How can trade goods reach workshops? In short; how will this benefit the kingdom the most. And I must confess that trade and naval matters are not areas of Castillian strengths. My kingdom barely has a fleet compared to Aragon. A matter I intend to adress and I have moored my full fleet in Valencia, putting it at the disposal of your king in support of his Naples campain. I honestly do not know what trade policies to adopt. I have never done so yet. But I have already said what I want these policies to achieve. Should anything change, I can assure this council that I will always seek out advice from bodies such as these and that I aim for policies that increase trade. Does this adress your question?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says you will seek advice from bodies such as ours. We are grateful. But seeking advice and heeding advice are different things. Castile has a Cortes. Aragón has Corts. Both give advice. Kings do not always listen. You say you want policies that increase trade. So do we. But whose trade? When a Castilian merchant and a Catalan merchant both want the same contract in Málaga, whose trade increases? This is not philosophy, Your Majesty. This is Tuesday.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Perhaps Your Majesty might offer us something... smaller. Not a trade policy—we understand that is premature. But a gesture. A sign of intent. When Catalan ships arrive at Málaga, will they be welcomed as friends? Will Your Majesty instruct your port officials to treat our merchants as... partners in this increased trade you envision?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, I can be specific in case of the example of the Catalan merchant and the Castillian merchant competing for the same contract on a tuesday. In the current situation, what would happen? Is the Castillian merchant in an advantage because he is trading in what essentially is Castillian territory?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: An excellent question, Your Majesty. At present, Granada's ports are... chaos. Forgive my bluntness. Málaga fell less than two years ago. Almería even more recently. The old Moorish trading houses are disrupted. The new Christian administration is still finding its feet. In such chaos, advantage flows to those with connections. Castilian merchants from Seville know your port officials. They speak the same language. They worship in the same churches. They have cousins and brothers-in-law in the customs houses. A Catalan merchant arrives in Málaga and he is... a foreigner. Tolerated, yes. But a foreigner. So when we ask whether Catalan ships will be welcomed as friends—we ask whether Your Majesty will instruct your officials that Catalans are not foreigners. That we are... partners. With the same rights, the same access, the same three days for a license. That is not a trade policy. That is a letter. A few sentences. 'Treat Aragonese merchants as you would Castilian merchants.' Nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have already told you what my policy should aim to accomplish. And treating Catalan merchants the same as Castillian ones would fit that narrative. If you want for me to draft official trade policy right here and right now, I must disappoint you. Imagine your king Alfonso drafting Aragonese trade policy while talking with Castillian traders in Castille! No, that would be unfair to those not represented. Do traders from Aragon and Castille meet somewhere? Maybe we should invite Portugal as well. Does such a structure yet exist? And if not, should we try and set up such a meeting?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: An international meeting of traders. A noble thought, Your Majesty. Truly. Such meetings have been proposed before. At Bruges. At Genoa. They take years to arrange. They produce... documents. Declarations of intent. Frameworks for future cooperation. Meanwhile, my ships sail to Málaga next month. Not next year. Next month. Your Majesty, I asked for a letter. A few sentences instructing your port officials to treat our merchants as equals. Not a policy. Not a treaty. A letter. Is that truly something that requires an international conference to decide?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. Can I have ink and quill? Lucia, would you be so kind as to draft this letter? Are there other issues we should include in the letter? Cooperation about piracy maybe? Or other matters?

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Barcelona's Consell de Cent to discuss trade concerns regarding Granada's conquered ports. The Catalans, led by Pere Joan de Sant Climent and Bernat Fiveller, press for concrete assurances that Catalan merchants will receive equal treatment in Castilian-controlled Granada. After initial evasions about international conferences, Juan finally agrees to draft a simple letter instructing his port officials to treat Aragonese merchants as equals to Castilians.

exchanges.speaker: gabriel_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I asked for a letter. A few sentences instructing your port officials to treat our merchants as equals. Not a policy. Not a treaty. A letter. Is that truly something that requires an international conference to decide?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. Can I have ink and quill? Lucia, would you be so kind as to draft this letter? Are there other issues we should include in the letter? Cooperation about piracy maybe? Or other matters?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall stirs. Whatever the merchants expected, it was not this. Fiveller stands frozen for a moment—a man who asked for a fish and has been handed the net. Sant Climent is already gesturing to a clerk, who scurries forward with writing materials. A small table is brought, set before Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: pere_sant_climent
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty is inclined to address matters of mutual concern... the piracy question is indeed pressing. A statement of intent—that Castile and Aragón will cooperate against the Salé corsairs—would be most welcome.

exchanges.speaker: gabriel_fiveller
exchanges.text: And perhaps... clarification on customs rates? If Catalan merchants are to be treated as equals, does this extend to the duties they pay? Equal access means little if we are taxed more heavily.

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: The silk, Majestic. You spoke of increasing trade. But trade in what? If Granada's silk floods our markets without restriction... Can the letter say something about... balance? That Your Majesty will not permit Granada's looms to destroy Valencia's? Some protection for those who weave, not only those who trade?

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: And information, Your Majesty. When Castile makes decisions that affect our merchants, will Barcelona be informed? Consulted? Or will we learn of new policies when our ships are turned away?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we start, I want to make sure that you all understand that I write this letter as king of Castille, aiming to increase cooperation and good standing between my kingdom and Aragon. Lets start with the pirates. The military orders have been ordered to construct a navy to fight pirates. Order them to focus their efforts on Sale. Coordinate with Aragon should they support this effort. We await what they should choose to commit. Harbour officials should know that Aragonese, Portugese and Castillian merchants should be treated equally and are subject to the same treatment and tax. Regarding the silk trade from Grenada, inform the duke of Grenada to develop policies to prevent Grenada silk to flood and disrupt the christian markets as we integrate Grenada into Castille. We adopt a policy where Portugese and Aragonese traders are informed about our taxes and any significant changes to them so traders can make better informed decisions. And finally, If Barcelona would be so kind as to host a meeting of traders of these kingdoms so we can further develop and discuss these issues, I would encourage the Castillian traders to attend, send a delegation and to work in good spirit towards a common purpose where trade flourishes. Does the council have anything else to add?

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says the Governor of Granada should 'develop policies to prevent disruption.' Forgive me, Majestic—but what policies? Tariffs on Moorish silk entering Christian markets? Quotas on how much can be sold? Policies can mean many things. My weavers need to know if they will have work next year.

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty offers to inform us of tax changes. We are grateful. But I asked whether Barcelona might be consulted. These are... different things. To be informed is to learn what has been decided. To be consulted is to speak before the decision is made.

exchanges.speaker: gabriel_fiveller
exchanges.text: And the equal treatment—this is most welcome. But does 'subject to the same tax' mean Catalan merchants pay what Castilians pay now? Or might all rates rise together, equally but... higher? We do not doubt Your Majesty's intentions. Only... words on parchment have a way of meaning different things to different readers.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am willing to accomodate this council in the spirit of cooperation. But cooperation goes both ways. Is this council ready to commit to consult Castillian traders on future trade policy of Aragon? I am not asking for it, but my traders would ask me right now to ask reciprocity in regards to a commitment to the same taxes and treatment of Castillian traders in Aragonese harbours. Before you ask for something, consider what it would look like if the shoe were on the other foot. I am taking very concrete steps to adress your concerns right now and I must leave my officials enough flexibility to effectively implement them. So I ask again, what issues would this council like to include as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall falls silent. Sant Climent's expression shifts—a flicker of something that might be respect, might be recalibration. He glances at his fellow consellers. Fiveller's jaw tightens almost imperceptibly.

exchanges.speaker: pere_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesty raises a... fair point. We have perhaps spoken as though this chamber sets policy for the Crown of Aragón. It does not. We govern Barcelona. We advise Her Majesty the Regent. But trade policy for the realm... That is a matter for the regency council. We cannot commit King Alfonso to reciprocal treatment of Castilian merchants in Aragonese ports. That is not our authority.

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: What we can commit, Your Majesty, is Barcelona. This city. This port. If Your Majesty instructs Málaga and Almería to treat Catalans as equals, this council can instruct Barcelona's harbor officials to extend the same courtesy to Castilians. Equal berthing. Equal licensing times. Equal treatment in the customs house.

exchanges.speaker: pere_sant_climent
exchanges.text: That much is within our power. And we would be... willing to put it in writing. A matching commitment. Barcelona's word alongside Castile's.

exchanges.speaker: gabriel_fiveller
exchanges.text: And the trading conference. If Barcelona hosts such a meeting, we commit our resources. Our halls. Our hospitality. That is something concrete we can offer.

exchanges.speaker: pere_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Is this acceptable, Your Majesty? Barcelona's commitment, in writing, to match your own terms—equal treatment, equal access—for Castilian merchants in our port? And our pledge to host and support the international gathering you propose?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That sounds fair. Is the letter finished Lucia? If it is, would you be so kind as to read it aloud for this council?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia sets down the quill and lifts the parchment, allowing the ink a moment to dry. She rises from the small table, her bearing regal despite the improvised setting. The hall falls utterly silent. One hundred men lean forward on their benches.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ahumada
exchanges.text: Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, to all officials, harbor masters, and servants of the Crown within Our realm, and to all Christian princes and merchants who may read these words, greeting. In the spirit of cooperation between Christian kingdoms and for the increase of honest trade, We do hereby decree and instruct as follows: First, that the Masters of the Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara shall direct their nascent naval forces toward the suppression of piracy, with particular attention to the corsairs of Salé who prey upon Christian shipping. They shall coordinate such efforts with the Kingdom of Aragón, should that realm choose to commit forces to this righteous cause. Second, that all harbor officials within Our realm, and most especially those of Málaga, Almería, and such other ports as fall under Our authority, shall treat merchants of Aragón and Portugal as they would treat merchants of Castile—subject to the same customs, the same duties, the same courtesies, and the same speed of licensing, with no distinction made upon the origin of their vessels. Third, that Don García López de Padilla, Governor of Granada, shall develop such policies as prevent the silk trade of that newly Christian territory from flooding and disrupting the markets of our brother kingdoms, so that the integration of Granada into Christendom proceeds with balance and justice to all. Fourth, that Our officials shall adopt a practice of informing the merchants of Portugal and Aragón of significant changes to customs rates and trading regulations, so that honest traders may make informed decisions. Fifth, that We encourage the city of Barcelona, should it choose to host a gathering of traders from the Christian kingdoms of Iberia, and We shall encourage Castilian merchants to attend such a meeting in good faith, sending proper delegation to work toward the common flourishing of trade. Given under Our hand, in the city of Barcelona, in the year of Our Lord fourteen hundred and thirty-four. Juan Rex

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall remains silent for a long moment. Then Sant Climent rises slowly from his chair.

exchanges.speaker: pere_sant_climent
exchanges.text: This is... more than we expected, Your Majesty. Barcelona will honor its commitment. Equal treatment for Castilian merchants in our port. In writing, as promised. Does the Consell de Cent consent to Barcelona's reciprocal commitment?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur rises—and then, starting from the merchants' benches and spreading through the artisans and citizens, a growing chorus: 'Sí. Sí. Sí.'

encounters.recap: Juan unexpectedly agrees to draft a comprehensive trade letter during the Barcelona council meeting. The letter establishes equal treatment for merchants across kingdoms, anti-piracy cooperation, Granada silk trade regulation, and merchant notification policies. Barcelona reciprocates with matching commitments for Castilian traders and pledges to host future trade conferences.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon returns precisely as the cathedral bells mark the hour. He escorts Juan and Lucia through the Palau Reial to a smaller receiving chamber—intimate, private, away from listening ears. The door opens. Hug Roger III, Count of Pallars Sobirà, rises from a chair by the window. He is perhaps fifty, grey-bearded, with the weathered face of a man who has spent decades managing mountain territories on the French border. His clothing is fine but not ostentatious—practicality over display. His bow is correct, nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Thank you for receiving me privately. What I have to say is... not for general ears.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course count. Let us go inside and listen to what you have to say.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is small, wood-paneled, lit by narrow windows overlooking an interior courtyard. Don Ramon withdraws, closing the door behind him with a soft click. Pallars does not sit until Juan and Lucia have taken their seats. When he does, he leans forward, elbows on knees, hands clasped—a soldier's posture, not a courtier's.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: I will not waste Your Majesty's time with pleasantries. Last night you showed me Alfonso's letter. You spoke of ending the Naples war quickly. Of the cost in coin and sons. This morning, I learned Your Majesty visited the Consell de Cent and gave them a royal charter promising equal treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's ports. The merchants are delighted. Don Guillem de Vic speaks of 'new beginnings.' Bishop Climent Sapera has apparently rediscovered his faith. Your Majesty moves quickly. In two days, you have done more for Aragonese interests than most visiting kings manage in a month. So I ask myself: why? What does the King of Castile want from Aragón that he works so hard to charm us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Who is to say that it is not Aragon who is charming me? The trade arrangements are reciprocal and Castilian merchants benefit from it as well when visiting Aragonese ports. And it is the bishop himself who discovered his calling again. There is nothing more beautiful than someone coming before God in humility. But I must confess that there is the matter of succession looming over us. If fate would have me be king of Aragon, then I want Aragon to know me. And I will want to know Aragon. That seems to be what everyone is asking me. Will I make Aragon a subject of Castile? Will I change trade arrangements? Will I honour existing feudal contracts? All while my cousin is still alive and well and will be hopefully for many years to come.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars listens without interruption. His weathered face reveals little—a man who has learned to keep his thoughts behind stone walls. When Juan finishes, the Count is silent for a long moment. He rises from his chair and moves to the window, looking out at the courtyard below.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks plainly. I respect that. Most men in your position would offer reassurances. Promises. Vows that nothing will change. You admit the truth—that you are here to be seen. To prepare for what may come. But Your Majesty will forgive me if I have heard kings speak of 'knowing' realms before. My grandfather heard Pedro of Castile speak of knowing Aragón. It did not end well for anyone. You ask what everyone fears. I will tell you what I fear. I fear that my sons will die in Italy for a crown Alfonso will never wear. I fear that Aragonese gold will continue flowing south while our mountain villages empty. I fear that when Alfonso finally falls from a Neapolitan wall or catches Roman fever, the man who inherits will see Aragón as a treasury to be raided for Castilian ambitions. Your Majesty has sent forty thousand florins to support Alfonso's Italian campaign. Catalan ships carry Castilian gold to fund a war that has already cost me a nephew and three cousins' sons. So when Your Majesty speaks of wanting to know Aragón—I must ask: do you wish to know us as partners? Or as the next source of men and money for the next war?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What would you do then? End the war? Capitulate? Will the Anjou accept a white peace? Or will they demand concessions? What would you do?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars' jaw tightens. The question has landed where Juan intended it. He is silent for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is quieter—harder.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: What would I do. Your Majesty asks me to solve in a sentence what Alfonso has failed to solve in twelve years. I would not have started it. But that counsel comes too late by a decade. If it were mine to decide? I would negotiate. Not capitulate—negotiate. René of Anjou is not his brother. He has Provence to manage, a claim to Naples he cannot enforce alone, and less stomach for endless war than Louis had. Would he accept a white peace? No. But he might accept a partition. Alfonso keeps Calabria and Sicily. René takes Naples itself. Both claim the title, neither fights for it. It is ugly. It satisfies no one fully. But it stops the bleeding. Your Majesty has influence with Alfonso now. Castilian gold speaks loudly. If you counseled partition rather than total victory... But that is not what Your Majesty has done. You have sent florins and ships to help Alfonso win. So I ask again—what manner of king will you be to us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You make an important point. The war should not have started in the first place. But we are past this now. You say that the war has cost Aragon gold and blood. A sentiment I share, the war has gone on for long enough. I have given Alfonso support in order to bring the war to a conclusion, not to let it drag along. I will visit him this year on my way to Constantinople and will council his on the situation. I will tell him that the war has to end, that ten years of war has drained his kingdom and he can ask no more of his subjects. Hopefully he will listen to me. Even if he cannot take all of Naples, the war has now come to a conclusion.

encounters.recap: In private chambers, Count Pallars confronts Juan about his true intentions regarding Aragonese succession and the costly Italian wars. After Juan admits his succession ambitions while promising to counsel Alfonso to end the Naples campaign, Pallars remains cautiously skeptical about whether Juan sees Aragón as partners or as resources to exploit.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You make an important point. The war should not have started in the first place. But we are past this now. You say that the war has cost Aragon gold and blood. A sentiment I share, the war has gone on for long enough. I have given Alfonso support in order to bring the war to a conclusion, not to let it drag along. I will visit him this year on my way to Constantinople and will council his on the situation. I will tell him that the war has to end, that ten years of war has drained his kingdom and he can ask no more of his subjects. Hopefully he will listen to me. Even if he cannot take all of Naples, the war has now come to a conclusion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars' expression shifts—not softening, but something behind the stone wall moves. He returns to his chair and sits. The posture is different now—less defensive, more attentive.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: You will counsel him to end the war. These are better words than I expected, Your Majesty. I will not pretend otherwise. But words are easy. Alfonso has heard counsel before. His own wife has begged him to come home. María has managed his kingdom for four years while he chases Italian dreams. He does not listen.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: So I must ask: when will you see Alfonso? You say you travel to Constantinople—that is east. Naples is... Will you go to him before Constantinople? After? Will this counsel happen in weeks, or months, or next year?

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: And what will you propose? You say the war must end. End how? Partition, as I suggested? Complete withdrawal? Some other arrangement? Telling Alfonso 'the war must end' means nothing. He believes he is winning. He will say 'yes, it will end—when I am crowned in Naples.' That is not what we need. Give me something concrete, Your Majesty. A route. A timeline. A proposal. Something I can take back to men who have buried their sons.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will travel to Rome first at the 1st of March. After my meeting with the pope, I will travel to Alfonso, wherever in Naples he is. I will tell him what I have told you. But I can only speak for myself, for Castille. I cannot speak on behalf of his own council or subjects. If you ask me to speak to my cousin on your behalf and maybe on behalf as well of others, then I could. But only with the blessing of the regency council. Otherwise, I would be meddling in the affairs of his kingdom. Remember that I hold no office or position in Aragon. If you want me to deliver a letter or statement from his kingdom concerning the state of the war and the kingdom, I can carry and deliver this message of course.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars' expression closes like a fortress gate. He is silent for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is flat—not angry, which would be easier to address, but tired.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A letter. I came here hoping to find a king who would use his influence. Who would tell Alfonso: the war ends, or the gold stops. Who would speak with the voice of a man who has power and is willing to wield it. Instead, Your Majesty offers to carry letters. To deliver messages. To wait for the regency council's blessing before speaking words that might actually matter.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I have buried a nephew and three cousins' sons in Italian soil, Your Majesty. Their mothers did not ask me to find someone who respects proper channels. They asked me to find someone who would stop the bleeding.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: You say you hold no office in Aragon. This is true. But you hold forty thousand florins of influence with Alfonso. You hold a fleet in Valencia's harbor. You hold the papal favor that legitimizes his claim. These are not nothing. These are power. And you choose to wrap that power in procedure and wait for authorization.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I thank Your Majesty for the audience. I will inform the Aragonese faction that the King of Castile is a man of careful words and proper process. God keep Your Majesty. And may your caution serve you better than boldness has served Alfonso.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do understand your position, and let me assure you that I will do what I can as best as I can to end the war. I have learned that smashing my fist on the table does not always yield the best results. I will pray for the fallen sons and the families who have lost them. Thank you for your time.

roll.outcome: Frustrated Disappointment. Pallars wanted an ally who would use his influence; Juan offers to carry letters. The careful deference to regency council authority feels like evasion.

encounters.recap: Juan promises to counsel Alfonso to end the Neapolitan war when he visits in March, but insists he can only speak for Castile and would need regency council blessing to represent Aragonese interests. Count Pallars, disappointed by Juan's cautious approach and offers to merely carry messages rather than use his influence decisively, departs with cold courtesy, viewing Juan as a king of careful words but little action.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells of Santa Maria del Mar toll the sixth hour. A knock at the chamber door. A servant enters, bowing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Don Ramon de Perellós requests an audience. He says he brings word from Her Majesty the Regent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon enters with his usual measured stride. His expression is neutral—carefully so—but there is something in the set of his shoulders that suggests the news is neither entirely good nor entirely bad. He bows.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. I have spoken with Her Majesty the Regent regarding the proposed council meeting. She consents to summoning the council.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A pause. The word but hangs unspoken in the air.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: However. Her Majesty has conditions. First, she will set the agenda. The council will discuss matters she determines are appropriate for discussion. Second, she will preside and control the proceedings. Third, certain topics—specifically, any formal discussion of succession, inheritance, or the union of crowns—shall remain off-limits until she has written to King Alfonso and received his reply. She emphasizes that this is not a refusal. It is... a structure. The council may discuss cooperation, trade, mutual defense, the Naples situation, the Constantinople expedition. But the question of what happens when—if King Alfonso dies without heir shall not be raised until the King himself has been consulted. Is this acceptable to Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course. And what is our role or position in this proceedings?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon's pause is almost imperceptible, but it is there. He moves to the window, a habit Juan has noticed—the man thinks better when looking at something other than the person he's speaking to.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: You are King of Castile. You hold no office in Aragón. You are not a member of the regency council. And yet you are the reason the council is being summoned. You are, as we have established, heir presumptive to the throne. And you are—family. Her Majesty proposes that you attend as an honored guest. You may speak when recognized by the presiding regent. You may offer counsel when asked. You may answer questions put to you directly. You may not introduce topics, call votes, or direct proceedings. In effect, Your Majesty would have voice but not authority. The council would hear you as they might hear an ambassador—with respect, with attention, but without obligation to follow your recommendations. Her Majesty believes this balances the... unusual nature of the situation. A visiting king who may one day rule, but does not rule yet.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is fine. Is there a date set for the meeting?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon nods, a flicker of approval crossing his features at Juan's easy acceptance.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Her Majesty suggests ten days hence. February sixth. Riders can reach Don Berenguer de Bardaxí and the Viscount of Rocabertí within two days. The Bishop of Girona within three. That allows time for travel and preparation. This would give Your Majesty approximately three weeks in Barcelona after the council meeting before your departure for Rome on the first of March. Time enough to address whatever arises from the discussions. Her Majesty also requests—though she frames it as a request, not a condition—that Your Majesty refrain from private discussions with faction leaders regarding council matters until the meeting itself. She wishes the council to hear proposals fresh, not... pre-negotiated. She understands that conversations have already occurred. She asks only that no new commitments be made before the council convenes. Shall I confirm these arrangements with Her Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, confirm these matters.

encounters.recap: María de Castilla agrees to summon the regency council with strict conditions: she will control the agenda and proceedings, succession topics are off-limits until Alfonso is consulted, and Juan may attend only as an honored guest with voice but no authority. The meeting is set for February 6th, with Juan accepting all terms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral rises from the heart of the Barri Gòtic like a prayer carved in stone. Gothic spires reach toward a winter sky, and the morning light filters through high windows, casting colored shadows across ancient flagstones. The royal party processes through the great doors: Juan and Lucia, Catalina carried by Inés, the household knights in their best doublets, Don Ramon and a contingent of Aragonese officials. The pews are full—word has spread that the King of Castile attends Mass, and Barcelona's faithful have come to see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bishop Francesc Climent Sapera waits at the altar in full vestments. He looks... different. There is something in his bearing that was not there two days ago. A straightness to the spine. A clarity in the eyes. Before the Mass begins, Juan approaches the bishop with his request.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: The fallen sons of Aragón. And their families. Yes. Yes, I will pray for them. This is... not a prayer I expected a Castilian king to request. But it is a prayer that is long overdue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bishop Climent Sapera preaches not of politics or crowns, but of service. Of the difference between power wielded for glory and power wielded for others. He speaks of Christ washing the feet of his disciples—a king becoming a servant. He does not mention Juan by name. He does not need to. And when he prays for the fallen sons—reading the names of those Barcelona families have lost in Italy, names he has clearly gathered in the night—something breaks open in the cathedral.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Weeping. Not performative grief, but the raw sound of wounds finally acknowledged. An old woman in black clutches her rosary and sobs. A grey-haired man bows his head, shoulders shaking. Somewhere near the back, a young widow holds her children close. The prayer continues for nearly ten minutes. Name after name. Family after family. When it ends, the silence is profound.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Afterward, as the congregation files out into the morning light, Juan notices several things: The Count of Pallars stands near the back of the cathedral. He was not there when the Mass began. His weathered face is unreadable, but he has not left. Don Guillem de Vic hovers near the doors, looking uncertain—the Naples prayer was not what the Neapolitan faction expected from their new ally. And María—Queen María—stands in a side chapel, alone, a candle flickering before her. She has been crying.

encounters.recap: Juan attends Mass at Barcelona's cathedral and requests prayers for the fallen sons of Aragón and their families. Bishop Climent Sapera delivers a powerful homily about service over glory and prays for the war dead by name, causing profound emotional release among the congregation. The event unexpectedly draws political figures and reveals Queen María's grief.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
THE DAYS BEFORE THE COUNCIL
January 28 - February 5, 1434
FESTA DE SANT PAU — January 29th
Catalina's eyes grow wide as saucers when the gegants appear.

The enormous painted figures—a king and queen, a Moor and a Christian knight, fantastical creatures three times the height of a man—sway through Barcelona's narrow streets on the shoulders of hidden carriers. Drums pound. Pipes wail. The crowd surges and cheers.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Big people! Very big people!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
She insists on being held aloft to see better, then insists on being put down to dance, then insists on being picked up again when the dragon gegant passes too close and she loses her nerve.

Lucia laughs more than Juan has heard in weeks.

The Barcelonans notice their visitors. Word spreads through the crowd: the Castilian king, the one who conquered Granada, he came to our festival. Some press closer to see. Others offer sweets to the little princess. An old woman presses a ribbon into Catalina's hands—a blessing, she says, for la princesita de la cuerda.

By evening, half of Barcelona has seen the King of Castile dancing awkwardly to Catalan drums while his daughter rides on his shoulders, shrieking with delight.

It is not dignified. It is not regal.

It is perfect.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
THE DRASSANES — January 30th
The royal shipyards smell of pitch, sawdust, and the sea.

Master shipwright Arnau Despujol walks Juan through the cavernous workspace where the ribs of three war galleys rise like the bones of great beasts. Catalan craftsmen labor with adze and saw, their movements practiced and precise.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: Thirty oars each side. Lateen sail for speed. Ram-prow reinforced with bronze.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
He shows Juan innovations—a new method of joining planks that reduces leakage, a design for oar-locks that allows faster deployment.

Juan asks questions. Detailed questions. Questions about tonnage and draft and the relative merits of nailed versus pegged construction.

Despujol's initial wariness gives way to something approaching enthusiasm.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: Your Majesty knows ships.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am learning. Castile has never been a naval power. That must change.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty ever wishes to send shipwrights to study our methods... Barcelona's techniques are no secret to those who ask properly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
LA LLOTJA — January 31st
The merchant exchange buzzes with activity—traders shouting prices, clerks scratching figures, runners dashing between stalls with messages and contracts.

Don Guillem serves as guide, introducing Juan to the leading merchant families. The Gualbes. The Santcliment. The Marquet.

They are courteous. They are cautious. They watch Juan the way they watch any new factor entering their market—assessing risk and opportunity.

Juan listens more than he speaks. He asks about trade routes, shipping costs, the challenges of dealing with Italian city-states. He does not promise. He does not commit. He learns.

The merchants take note. A king who listens is unusual. A king who asks about shipping costs is unprecedented.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
THE CROSSBOW GUILD — February 1st
The guild's practice ground lies outside the city walls. Targets stand at varying distances—some stationary, some mounted on pivots to swing unpredictably.

The crossbowmen are proud men, veterans of city defense and occasional mercenary service. They eye Juan with professional skepticism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
Juan's first bolts fly true enough. He is competent—trained, as any prince must be. But the guild's champions outshoot him handily, their bolts clustering in target centers while his scatter more widely.

He takes the defeat with grace.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see why Barcelona's walls have never fallen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina, watching from a safe distance with Lucia and Inés, demands to try. She is given an unstrung practice bow to hold. She aims it at a pigeon and declares victory when it flies away.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
FALCONRY IN COLLSEROLA — February 2nd
The hills above Barcelona offer crisp winter air and sweeping views of the sea.

The Count of Cardona—whose son Bernat has become Catalina's reluctant playmate—hosts the hunt. Several Aragonese nobles attend, including, unexpectedly, the Count of Pallars.

Pallars keeps his distance for most of the morning. But when Juan's falcon brings down a fine heron, the old count rides closer.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A good kill.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The falcon did the work.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A modest king. Unusual.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They ride in silence for a time. Then Pallars speaks again, quietly:

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: The council meets in four days. I have spoken with Don Ramon about the message to Alfonso. We are... drafting language.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
THE BOQUERIA MARKET — February 3rd
Catalina is in paradise.

The market sprawls in organized chaos—fish gleaming on ice, meat hanging from hooks, pyramids of oranges and lemons, baskets of almonds and dried figs. Vendors call their wares in rapid Catalan.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Fish! Big fish!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Bird! Dead bird!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Smell bad!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
Lucia purchases honey cakes. Catalina devours two before anyone can stop her, then demands a third 'for the horse'—meaning her wooden horse, back at the palace.

The market vendors are charmed. Word spreads. By afternoon, someone has given Catalina a small basket of candied almonds, a ribbon for her hair, and a tiny wooden cat that a craftsman carved on the spot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
A LETTER ARRIVES — February 4th
Don Ramon brings it personally.

María receives it in private. She does not share its contents immediately.

But that evening, she sends word through Don Ramon: 'Her Majesty wishes to inform His Majesty of Castile that the council meeting will proceed as planned. His Majesty's presence is... welcome.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text:
THE EVE OF THE COUNCIL — February 5th
The absent members have arrived. Don Berenguer de Bardaxí, weathered and watchful. The Viscount of Rocabertí, proud and silent. The Bishop of Girona, rotund and thoughtful.

Barcelona hums with tension and anticipation. Everyone knows the council meets tomorrow. Everyone knows the King of Castile will attend. Everyone wonders what will be said.

Lucia finds Juan in their chambers, watching the sunset over the harbor.

encounters.recap: Over nine days, Juan immerses himself in Barcelona's cultural life with Catalina and Lucia. They attend the Festa de Sant Pau, visit the royal shipyards, explore the merchant exchange, practice with crossbowmen, hunt with Aragonese nobles, and wander the Boqueria market. The public activities gradually warm Barcelona's reception of the Castilian king, while private encounters begin to thaw relations with key figures like the Count of Pallars, setting the stage for the crucial regency council meeting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon brings it personally.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: From His Majesty King Alfonso. Addressed to Her Majesty the Regent.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María receives it in private. She does not share its contents immediately. But that evening, she sends word through Don Ramon:

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Her Majesty wishes to inform His Majesty of Castile that the council meeting will proceed as planned. His Majesty's presence is... welcome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It is not warmth. But the word welcome was not in her vocabulary three days ago.

encounters.recap: A letter arrives from King Alfonso addressed to Queen María. She reads it privately and afterward sends word through Don Ramon that Juan's presence at the upcoming council meeting is welcome—a subtle but significant softening of her stance.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council chamber of the Palau Reial is smaller than Juan expected—intimate, even. A rectangular table of dark oak dominates the space, surrounded by high-backed chairs bearing the arms of Aragón. Tapestries depicting the conquest of Valencia line the walls. Morning light streams through narrow windows. The councillors are already assembled when Juan and Lucia enter.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. Your Majesty. The Council of Aragón welcomes you as honored guests.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The word guests carries weight. She gestures to two chairs set slightly apart from the table—visible, included, but not of the council.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Please. Be seated.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Her Majesty the Regent has prepared an agenda for today's proceedings. With Your Majesty's permission? First: the matter of trade cooperation between the kingdoms, including the recent agreements with the Consell de Cent. Second: the Constantinople expedition and Castile's intentions regarding aid to the Emperor. Third: the Naples campaign and its... current state. Her Majesty has ruled that discussion of succession, inheritance, or the formal union of crowns shall be reserved until King Alfonso has been consulted. Does Your Majesty of Castile have any questions before we proceed?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No questions. If I may thank the council for inviting me and my queen. We will be honoured observers.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: The Consell de Cent has provided a summary of their recent agreements with His Majesty of Castile. Equal treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's ports. Reciprocal treatment for Castilian merchants in Barcelona. A commitment to host an international trading conference. Don Guillem de Vic has also prepared agreements with the Gualbes banking family establishing frameworks for financial cooperation.

exchanges.speaker: viscount_of_rocaberti
exchanges.text: A moment. Before we celebrate agreements made outside this council's authority, perhaps we should understand what was actually promised. Your Majesty wrote a letter to Castilian port officials. Signed and sealed in Barcelona, in the hall of the Consell de Cent. A letter establishing trade policy for Granada. Policy that affects Aragonese merchants. Did Your Majesty consult this council before signing? Did Your Majesty consult the Regent? Or did Your Majesty simply... decide?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is very quiet. The moment stretches. The Viscount's question hangs in the air. Around the table, councillors watch—some looking at Juan, others at María. María regards Juan for a long moment. Her expression is unreadable. Then she inclines her head, the barest fraction.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile may respond to the Viscount's question.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is true what you say. I have indeed written a letter to my officials in Castille. An act to address concerns of Aragonese merchants and done in full openness and transparency. I have nothing to hide. But I think the question the count is actually asking is this: Is Juan undermining the authority of both the regency council and the king himself? Would he not have asked permission before writing to his own court? To those questions I say this. I fully respect the authority of both the king and this council. Witnesses to the meeting can attest that I specifically stated this publicly. María and king Alfonso know of my ambition to improve Christian trade and my policies should come as no surprise. I would never draft policies regarding a kingdom other than my own. But when it concerns my own kingdom, I require no permission from other kingdoms as well.

exchanges.speaker: maria
exchanges.text: Enough. Viscount Rocabertí. Did I hear you correctly? Did you just question a sovereign king's right to instruct his own officials in his own kingdom? You merely suggested that the King of Castile requires our permission to govern Castile. You have insulted a crowned monarch. In my council. Under my authority. His Majesty of Castile came to this council as an honored guest. He accepted conditions. He has shown this body respect that—that he did not owe us. And you repay that courtesy by questioning his sovereignty? The letter His Majesty wrote instructs Castilian officials to treat Catalan merchants as equals. As equals. Is there anyone here who wishes to object to that? Anyone who believes our merchants should be treated worse in Granada's ports? I thought not. His Majesty of Castile has answered the question satisfactorily. The matter is closed. Don Ramon, proceed with the agenda.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Guillem rises, his confidence restored. He begins outlining the Gualbes banking arrangements, but the room has shifted. Councillors who were watching Juan with suspicion now watch him with something else—curiosity, perhaps. Reassessment. The Count of Pallars catches Juan's eye across the table. He nods. Once. Barely perceptible. But it is there.

roll.outcome: Rocabertí overplayed. The attack backfires—Juan's response exposes it as unreasonable. María intervenes to rebuke the Viscount for questioning a sovereign's right to instruct his own officials. The council moves forward with Juan's credibility enhanced.

encounters.recap: At the Regency Council meeting, Juan faces a hostile challenge from Viscount Rocabertí about signing trade agreements without permission. Juan's direct, transparent response acknowledging the facts while defending his sovereign rights impresses the council. María sharply rebukes Rocabertí for questioning Juan's sovereignty, dramatically shifting the room's dynamics in Juan's favor.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: The potential is significant. Granada's trade alone could generate returns of fifteen to twenty percent annually for participating houses—both Catalan and Castilian.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: And the Church's interests? The tithes from this new commerce—how are they to be divided between dioceses?

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: That... would require further consultation, Your Excellency.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: Indeed it would. I trust such consultation will occur before agreements are finalized.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: Her Majesty, shall we note that ecclesiastical implications require separate negotiation?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: So noted. The trade agreements are accepted in principle, pending resolution of Church matters. The second item. Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The mood shifts. This is not commerce—this is war, crusade, the fate of Christendom's eastern bulwark. Don Berenguer de Bardaxí speaks for the first time. He is perhaps sixty, with a soldier's bearing and a diplomat's careful eyes.

exchanges.speaker: don_berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: We have heard reports that His Majesty of Castile has committed substantial forces to Constantinople's defense. One thousand knights. Sixty thousand florins. We have also heard that His Majesty intends to travel there personally.

exchanges.speaker: don_berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: Aragón has interests in the eastern Mediterranean. Our merchants trade in Constantinople. Our ships sail those waters. If Castile commits to a major military expedition in waters where Aragonese vessels operate, this council should understand the implications.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: And the costs. Another crusade. Another war requiring gold and men. We have experience with such ventures.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile may speak to the Constantinople matter, if he wishes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me state that I am not on crusade to fight the Ottomans. I am going to Constantinople to aid fellow Christians in need. I will offer them sanctuary in my kingdom. They can leave their city and prevent further bloodshed in a war that can never be won. If they refuse to leave, I will repair their walls as promised and wish them good luck and leave with my men and knights. I will not let my men die for a hopeless cause. Only if I think we can really win, if not only Castille, but also other christian kingdoms are serious about committing to war with the Ottomans, will I commit to war. How will this affect Aragon? Either way, the Greeks have asked for help and I have responded. How they wish to continue is up to them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber stirs as Juan finishes. Councillors exchange glances—calculating, assessing.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: If Constantinople's trade survives—and if Castilian forces help ensure it survives—Catalan merchants stand to benefit. The eastern routes are... There are commercial considerations.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: Three options. Evacuation. Repair and departure. Or war, if others commit. This is... not what I expected to hear.

exchanges.speaker: don_berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: His Majesty speaks of grand strategy. Of Ottoman banners on Christian coasts. But I asked about Aragonese interests. Our merchants. Our ships. Our sailors. If Castilian warships operate in waters where Catalan trading vessels sail, what arrangements exist to prevent... confusion? If Constantinople falls while Catalan merchants are within its walls, what obligations does Castile assume? If war comes, and Castile withdraws—as His Majesty has wisely reserved the right to do—what happens to Aragonese subjects caught in the aftermath?

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: And the ecclesiastical dimensions. Has His Majesty consulted with Rome regarding the reunion of the Churches? The Greeks are schismatics. Aid to Constantinople carries theological implications that—

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Gentlemen. His Majesty of Castile has outlined his intentions. He has not asked Aragón for troops, ships, or gold. He has not asked us to commit to anything. The question before this council is not whether we approve of Castile's expedition. It is whether Aragón has specific concerns that should be communicated—and whether any coordination might benefit our merchants and sailors who operate in those waters. Don Berenguer raises practical questions. Does His Majesty wish to address them, or shall we note them for future discussion through proper diplomatic channels?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can Don Berenguer re-state his questions so I may address them?

exchanges.speaker: don_berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: First. Castilian warships will operate in the eastern Mediterranean. Catalan trading vessels sail those same waters. What arrangements will His Majesty make to ensure Catalan vessels are recognized and protected, not harassed, by Castilian naval forces? Second. Catalan merchants maintain warehouses and factors in Constantinople. If the city falls, does Castile accept any obligation to evacuate Aragonese subjects? Third. His Majesty wisely reserves the right to withdraw if the cause proves hopeless. But if Castile decides to leave and the Ottomans close the straits, what warning will His Majesty provide? What coordination, so that our ships are not left stranded while Castile sails home?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Castille is not currently at war with anyone. There is no need to capture any vessels or for any hostile action. Do your ships not carry the flag of your kingdom? I assure you that my captains know of your flags and will not regard you as the enemy. I will also make every intent to communicate to the Ottomans that I act on behalf of Castille and that Aragon is not involved in any conflict. Regarding your second point, you have my word that I shall grant aid and sanctuary to any Aragonese brothers and other christians who wish to leave. I will not leave anyone to their fate. I will use my fleet to break any blockade and make sure everyone gets home safely should this occur.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Berenguer listens without expression. When Juan finishes, he is silent for a long moment.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the Aragonese council about Constantinople, outlining three conditional options rather than crusading rhetoric. He offers to evacuate Greeks, repair walls, or fight only if other kingdoms commit. Despite his pragmatic approach, councillors press him on practical concerns about Aragonese merchant safety and coordination in Ottoman waters.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Regarding your second point. My commitment to repair the walls and to provide extra knights serve to buy us time to evacuate should they choose to do so. And you have my word that I shall grant aid and sanctuary to any Aragonese brothers and other christians who wish to leave. I will not leave anyone to their fate. This applies to the third point as well. I will use my fleet to break any blockade and make sure everyone gets home safely should this occur.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: Flags. Yes. Our ships carry the bars of Aragón. Castilian captains should know them. The second and third points... His Majesty offers his word. Sanctuary for Aragonese subjects. Aid in evacuation. A fleet to break blockades. These are not small promises, Your Majesty. A king's word in a council chamber is one thing. A treaty signed and sealed is another.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: I have commanded men in the field. I know how campaigns unfold. Promises made in palaces are forgotten when blood flows and ships burn. I do not doubt His Majesty's intent. But intent is not obligation. If His Majesty were willing to formalize these commitments—a written undertaking, perhaps, stating that Castilian forces will extend protection to Aragonese subjects in Constantinople and provide evacuation assistance in the event of the city's fall...

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: Such a document would also clarify ecclesiastical jurisdiction over any Aragonese souls in His Majesty's care.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The council would find written assurances... reassuring. If His Majesty is willing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course sister, I will sign this document immediately if it serves to provide assurance to this council. If I understand this correctly, it will establish an obligation of Castille to protect the interest and souls of Aragonese subjects without any reciprocitital arrangements. Maybe we could include that Aragon shall also aid in the evacuation to the best of their ability, should such a situation occur? I seems fair to me since both kingdoms share the same interest.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber shifts. Don Berenguer's jaw tightens almost imperceptibly. He asked for a written commitment and received one—along with a request he did not anticipate. María's composure holds, but something flickers behind her eyes.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_mur
exchanges.text: His Majesty raises a fair point. Reciprocity is... customary in such arrangements.

exchanges.speaker: viscount_of_rocaberti
exchanges.text: Reciprocity? His Majesty asks us to commit Aragonese ships to a war in the East? After everything we have heard about the cost of foreign adventures?

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: His Majesty did not ask for ships in war. He asked for aid in evacuation. These are different things. Though the line between them can blur when Ottoman galleys are involved.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: The Church's position on mutual Christian aid is clear. We are obligated to assist fellow believers in peril. But obligation in principle and obligation in treaty are...

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: This council cannot commit the Crown of Aragón to military obligations without the King's consent. However. If His Majesty is willing to sign a document pledging Castilian protection for Aragonese subjects in Constantinople... This council can recommend to King Alfonso that Aragón offer reciprocal assistance. A recommendation is not a commitment. But it carries weight.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: A letter from this council, urging His Majesty King Alfonso to formalize mutual aid in the event of Constantinople's fall. Attached to His Majesty of Castile's signed undertaking.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Is this acceptable? Your commitment now, and our strong recommendation to the King—delivered alongside the other matters we shall communicate to him regarding this council's deliberations?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This council is well aware that I will meet with king Alfonso in a few months time and we will be sure to discuss this matter as well. But I do have to raise a concern. If I arrive with Castille already committed and a recommendation from this council that Alfonso reciprocate the arrangement, I may bring him in a difficult position. Castille has already committed and with a recommendation from his council, he practically has no option but to agree. If this council can not commit to sign as well - a decision I respect - then I propose I discuss this matter with the king directly so we may both sign at the same time. This council can write him a letter to carry this council's considerations if they want. Will this adress this council's concerns regarding Constantinople?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber falls silent. María stares at Juan. For a long moment, her composed mask slips—not into anger or suspicion, but something closer to surprise.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile has just voluntarily surrendered an advantage.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: He has.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: This is... an honorable approach. Two sovereigns negotiating as equals, signing together. The proper order of things.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You would have had us in a corner. Castile committed, the council recommending, Alfonso with no graceful way to refuse. And you chose not to.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_mur
exchanges.text: Then the matter of Constantinople shall be noted as follows: His Majesty of Castile will discuss mutual protection of subjects with King Alfonso directly. This council will prepare a letter outlining our considerations and concerns for His Majesty to carry. Is this acceptable?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The third item. Naples.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Count Pallars. You indicated that you and Don Ramon have been drafting language regarding a message to the King. Will you present it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I listen

encounters.recap: Juan negotiates the Constantinople issue by proposing mutual protection of subjects, but when offered advantage through unilateral commitment, he chooses to wait and negotiate directly with Alfonso as equals. The council is surprised by his honorable approach, earning their respect and defusing potential conflict over reciprocal obligations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars rises from his chair. He is not a man given to theatrics—his movements are deliberate, economical. He produces a folded document from his doublet and spreads it on the table before him.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: This council has long debated how to address the Naples question with His Majesty King Alfonso. Some believe we should demand immediate withdrawal. Others believe we should support the campaign to its conclusion. For twelve years, we have done neither—sending gold and men while wringing our hands.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks around the table.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: Don Ramon and I have attempted to draft language that this council might actually agree upon. Language that speaks truth without ultimatum. That honors the King's sacrifices while acknowledging the kingdom's exhaustion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He picks up the document.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: With Her Majesty's permission, I will read it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María nods, her face very still. Pallars reads the draft letter to King Alfonso, speaking of admiration for his victories but warning of the kingdom's exhaustion from twelve years of war. The letter asks Alfonso to weigh whether Naples is worth the cost of the kingdom that must wear it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars sets down the document. The chamber is silent. Don Guillem's face has gone pale. The Viscount of Rocabertí looks as though he wants to speak but is restraining himself.

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: This is the draft. It has not been approved. It is before the council for discussion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretches. Don Guillem is the first to move. He shifts in his chair, his face a mask of carefully controlled distress.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: The letter is... eloquent. But I wonder if 'swiftly' is not already within reach. His Majesty's recent victories—Calabria turning to his banner, Queen Joanna's envoys—

exchanges.speaker: count_pallars
exchanges.text: Queen Joanna has sent envoys before. Twice she has offered adoption. Twice she has revoked it. Joanna's word is written in sand.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
